title: west kintyre wind farm reaches turbine milestone
story: Blary Hill Wind Farm, which started construction in summer last year, has now entered the final phase of commissioning, testing, and reinstatement work ahead of completion in early .Once fully operational, the MW wind farm will be capable of generating clean, low-carbon and low-cost renewable electricity for around , homes, making an important contribution towards achieving Scotland#s target of net zero carbon emissions by , according to developer RES, the world#s largest independent renewable energy company.#This is a major milestone for the project and we#re pleased with how smoothly the turbine deliveries and turbine erection work has gone over the last few months,# said Iain MacCallum, construction project manager at RES.#It has been one of the busiest phases of construction – not just on site but also for the area with the delivery of the turbine components – so we are especially grateful to the local community for their patience during this particularly busy time.#We#ve also worked hard to ensure that we connect with the local supply chain and involve them in the project.#Blary Hill is expected to create more than £. million of inward investment for the local economy during the wind farm#s construction and first year of operation and we#ve seen this first-hand by working with businesses such as Donald McLean Contractors which undertook some of the civil works Peter McKerral  Co hauliers, which extracted the timber from the site Campbeltown Motor Company, which supplied some of our site vehicles G McNaughton  Son, which provided plant hire and McFadyens Transport hauliers, which helped todeliver the  turbine components to site by abnormal load.#We also recruited labour operatives from Campbeltown job centre – and this all adds up at a local level.#Margaret Pratt, convener of West Kintyre Community Council, added: #We are very grateful for the care and consideration that RES has shown to our community during the construction of Blary Hill Wind Farm, particularly during Covid.#It has kept us consulted and up-to-date with the project and coordinated things well locally.#It#s also been good to see its commitment to involving the local supply chain with the project as this further benefits the local area.#We look forward to the wind farm being fully commissioned early next year.#In addition to the inward investment delivered through the local supply chain, RES says the community will benefit from essential upgrades to the Barr Glen road, new parking  in Glenbarr village, and a £, contribution towards an amenity project.Blary Hill Wind Farm will also deliver around £. million in business rates to Argyll and Bute Council.

title: council reaffirms commitment to tackling climate change
story: At a meeting of the full council last Thursday, members approved a motion renewing the pledge, originally made in September , to play its part in the world-wide effort to address global warming.The motion referred to the publication of the recent United Nations Climate Change Report which outlined the scale of the threat, warning that the situation is now a #code red for humanity#.It also highlighted just some of the actions the council has been taking in recent years to ensure Argyll and Bute further improves its current positive position and low carbon emissions levels.#While we are fortunate in having one of the lowest carbon footprints anywhere in the UK, we also recognise that there is no room for complacency on this critical subject,# said council leader Robin Currie.#We are committed to helping the drive to tackle the impacts of climate change at local, regional and national levels wherever possible.#This is a key priority for the council and, building on the actions we are already taking through the decarbonisation plan, we will work with our communities and our partners to explore all possible options to tackle the threat which climate change presents.#

title: curtain lifted on pupils animation project
story: Rhunahaorine, Clachan and Glenbarr Primary Schools received a substantial grant from the West Kintyre Windfarm Trust in January  to work on a partnership project with Campbeltown Picture House.The idea came from a parent, after several other Kintyre schools were visited in January  by Aardman Animations, creators of some of the UK#s best loved characters, including Wallace and Gromit.After successfully applying to the windfarm trust to fund their own animation workshops, it looked likely to be cancelled because of the pandemic.However, the windfarm trust was understanding and allowed the grant be carried over into this financial year.Ellen Mainwood, the cinema#s manager, assisted with the application and was able to support the bid in kind.The money from the windfarm trust enabled the hiring of Alasdair Satchel, a theatre, film and podcast maker, to lead the children in creating animations.One Friday in September, the children had their first session and were welcomed at the cinema by deputy manager Mhairi Hendrie.A behind-the-scenes tour took the children to see the cinema#s biomass boiler and laser projector, both energy-saving additions when the building was refurbished between  and .#We were also given an opportunity to learn about the long and ied history of this amazing establishment, including the lucky shoe found under the floorboards when the cinema was renovated,# said Catriona Brown, head teacher at Rhunahaorine Primary School.#We also learned about the development of cinematography and how this changed cinema forever.#This grabbed the attention of the children as well as the popcorn storeroom!#Perhaps they will incorporate some of these things in their animations but, ultimately, the children will be given free choice to select their subject as some have been imagining things already.#Over the next six months, it is hoped the children will create and learn to film their own animations.All of the children – and adults – are very excited to be taking part keep an eye out in the Courier for updates as the project develops.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: fundraising-help-man-realise-american-dream
story: John McGrogan, , who lives in Prestonpans, met Hailey, his American girlfriend of three years, on Twitter and is now hoping to make a permanent move Stateside to join her in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, where she is studying.He is busy raising funds to start his new le in the US through his hobby of livestreaming worldwide on his Facebook page Running Crutches, saying: ldquoIt is a great creative outlet and I can entertain thousands of people at the press of a button.John provides the free entertainment on Facebook gaming streams and is raising funds via PayPal, adding: ldquoI let people knowthey want to support my move to America and want to help fund it to press the donation link in the description of all my streams.ldquoI donrsquot ask people to donate ndash I let people decidethey want to themselves.ldquoI donrsquot have a minimum amount that can be given because every penny truly does count.He said that his streams were not pointed towards a specic audience, adding: ldquoI do mainly [combat game]Warzone and do a lot within the realms of that game, whether it be playing competitive matches and tournaments.ldquoI do a lot of challenge streams where I get my viewers to set me challenges and parameters that I use in the games. I would describe them as ied but specic to Warzone.John, who is originally from Eskview in Musselburgh and is a former Campie Primary School pupil, was diagnosed with osteosarcoma ndash bone cancer ndash just above his knee at the age of  while he was a pupil at Musselburgh Grammar School and had to leave in the middle of his fourth year.He said that he replaced classes with attending chemotherapy appointments and surgery.ldquoIt was only after the first few weeks where it reality hit and the effects of the chemo kicked in that I realised le would never be the same again, he said.ldquoI had three dferent types of chemo and a lot of surgeries that lasted until .ldquoI like to call my last cancer surgery my amputation because that was the end of the leg that held the tumour.ldquoI still have immense phantom pains from the removal of the limb and have acute pain in the stump that was left, so every day it feels like Irsquom still having this battle with cancer that I thought would finish back then.John has a prosthetic leg and will start to walk on it again once the pain from his surgeries has subsided. He is unable to work at present.John has not seen Hailey for more than  days due to borders in America being closed.He is hoping he can raise enough funds to cover the cost of his move to the ldquoland of opportunity, including visas, and is also eventually hoping to get his own house and American citizenship.John said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic in itself wouldnrsquot have been a problem for me.ldquoIrsquom fully vaccinated and have never had the disease.ldquoThe only thing that stopped us was the US travel ban, which has had the country closed for almost two years now.John, who lives with his parents and two brothers, added: ldquoHaving cancer really put things into perspective. I canrsquot just sit around and not do the things I dream about in le ndash I just have got to go for it. The only thing holding me back is the cost but, once I get through this first gate, it should be smooth sailing.His Facebook page is facebook RunningCrutches

title: dad-sister-running-marathon-duncan-mcleans-memory
story: Iain McLean and daughter Annabel will pound the streets during the London Marathon on Sunday alongside thousands of other runners.The duo are representing the Brain Tumour Charity, following the death of Duncan McLean five years ago.The former Gullane Primary School and Musselburghrsquos Loretto School pupil died from a glioblastoma multormebrain tumour in February  ndash just three days after he was admitted to hospital with severe headaches.Sixty-year-old Iain told the Courier that Duncan had always wanted to complete a marathon.Now, Duncanrsquos dad and -year-old sister Annabel will take on the .-mile race in his memory.Iain, who lives in Gullane, said: ldquoIt has kept us doing the ious fundraising things and working with the charity.ldquoIt is good for us to keep people thinking about Duncan and doing public things rather than just cowering away in a darkened room.ldquoIt is five years on but it is still tough, to be honest.Iain had been due to line up in London last April but the event was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.The famous race was rescheduled for October but, due to the pandemic, it was only elite runners taking on the challenge.Now, Iain will be joined by his daughter, who is a doctor in Glasgow, in representing the charity.Training started in November  and Iain was now looking forward to the race getting under way and seeing the sights broadcast to millions on the BBC.He said: ldquoThe landmarks will be fantastic.ldquoIt is great and I am looking forward to it.ldquoWe are going to have a nice weekend in London, my we is coming down to support us and we are meeting with other people.To support Iain and Annabel, go to justgiving fundraising iain-mclean

title: haddington-corn-exchange-may-not-reopen-2022
story: An pound, refurbishment of Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange was due to start in February .That was delayed due to ldquofurther intrusive survey work and the refurbishment was then further hampered by the coronavirus pandemic.Now, community councillors have been told that the prominent Court Street building might not reopen until next year.Fiona McEwan, secretary of Haddington and District Community Council, discussed the issue at the grouprsquos virtual meeting.She said: ldquoI spoke to [East Lothian] Council and there is still snagging work getting done.ldquoI cannot see it being open before November. I was told it is more likely to be the beginning of next year before it starts getting rented out.The venue, which has hosted everything from concerts by the likes of Fish and The Proclaimers to blood donor sessions, charity fundraisers and a iety of community organisations, dates back to .Haddington Festival, which has been cancelled for the last two years, is usually based in the building, which is also used by the community council during the festive period.The refurbishment, which has resulted in the main hall being out of use for more than two years, involved new roof lights being installed in the main hall, as well as roof repairs and timber flooring being replaced.A new storage area, new kitchen and additional toilets have also been created, with minor decoration of the building to be carried out.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that there was still minor work, including polishing and painting, being carried out in the building.But one of the main problems was still the coronavirus pandemic, despite the recent relaxing of restrictions.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe main issue, in common with other public buildings, is a lack of staff to maintain and clean the buildings prior to use and afterwards.ldquoOur facilities management resources are very stretched just now and cleaning staff in particular are prioritising statutory services such as schools.ldquoAn interesting aside to this is the impact within the councilrsquos own buildings, as we currently have a number of toilets and shared kitchen areas in John Muir House reduced for staff to access to provide cleaning support where.

title: ormiston-teenager-shares-gaelic-experiences-television-show
story: Tawana Maramba , who lives on Wildflower Crescent, appears in Trusadh: Afro-Gagraveidheil ndash Afro-Gaels, a documentary that follows Cass Ezeji, a Gaelic-speaking singer with Scottish and Nigerian roots.Throughout the programme, Cass explores her relationship with Gaelic culture and history.She meets Gaelic speakers of African and Caribbean descent to discuss how they connect to the language and culture while also talking to experts to uncover the Gaelrsquos role in the slave trade.Tawana, , discusses her education at a Gaelic school and how she enjoys singing in Gaelic. She also teaches Gaelic singing.Tawanarsquos parents are from Zimbabwe and have taught her the Shona language, a Bantu language of the Shona people of Zimbabwe.Tawana was born in Edinburgh, moving to Ormiston two years ago. She also has a strong connection to Zimbabwe culture.She attended Tollcross Primary School in Edinburgh, which offered the only Gaelic medium primary education in Edinburgh and the Lothians.Tawana stayed there until a new Gaelic primary school opened in Bonnington, Leith, called Bun-sgoil Taobh na Pagraveirce.Afterwards, she attended James Gillespiersquos High School, also in Edinburgh.Tawana runs an after-school club in Bun-sgoil Taobh na Pagraveirce, teaching Gaelic to pupils.She said: ldquoI feel some people react like: lsquoOh, you speak Gaelic !rsquo But Irsquom quite proud of that.ldquoIt plays a huge part in my le. There are lots of things I wouldnrsquot be doingit wasnrsquot for Gaelic. Irsquom grateful that I can speak Gaelic.Trusadh: Afro-Gagraveidheil ndash Afro-Gaels airs on BBC ALBA on Monday at pm and will be available on BBC iPlayer for  days.

title: 50-yard-drive-pub-proves-costly-north-berwick-man
story: Andrew Watt, , was pulled over by police officers at the townrsquos High Street on November , .He was breathalysed and the reading showed he had mg of alcohol in ml of breath, more than double the legal limit of mg.Wattrsquos solicitor Cameron Tait said that his client had been having a business meeting at a pub in the town when his colleague was called away unexpectedly.Mr Tait said Watt had consumed ldquotwo beers and had started on a third when he decided to head home after the meeting came to an early close.Edinburgh Sherf Court heard that police officers then pulled Watt over due to his vehicle having a ldquofaulty brake light after he had only driven  yards.The court also heard of a second incident where police were called out to Wattrsquos home on the townrsquos Keppel Road on July  last year.Two officers had cause to speak to Watt about a possible road traffic offence and he was said to have pushed the officers away from him.The police managed to ldquogain control of the accused and he was taken into a marked police vehicle.While in the vehicle, Watt was asked about the identity of the driver of one of his workrsquos vans earlier that day and he was said to have simply replied ldquono.Lawyer Mr Tait said that Watt had been walking into his home when the officers ldquobarged into his property.He was askedhe had been driving a vehicle that day, which he denied. Watt then carried out a drink-drive breath test which he subsequently failed.Mr Tait told the court that any driving ban would be ldquodevastating to the business owner and that he had  employees and needed his licence to get to jobs and for pricing jobs in the evening.Sherf Peter McCormack heard that Watt also had a previous conviction for drink-driving from  and, due to him committing the same offence within  years, he had no option but to issue a y road ban.Watt was banned from driving for three years and fined a total of pound.The sherf allowed Watt to take part in a drink-drive rehabilitation scheme whichsuccessfully completed would see the ban reduced by a quarter.Watt was also fined pound to mark the offence with the police at his home last year.His not guilty plea to the second drink-drive offence was accepted by the Crown.Watt pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at High Street, North Berwick, on November , .He also pleaded guilty to resisting arrest and failing to give the officers the name and date of birth of the driver of a vehicle at Keppel Road, North Berwick, on July  last year.

title: east-lothians-first-crematorium-set-approved-old-craighall
story: Crematorium operators Westerleigh Grouprsquos plans for a new facility aim to ensure that funeral corteges do not have to take more than  minutes to reach their final destination.And they say that their plans for East Lothian will mean grieving families no longer face the ldquounacceptable delays which can be caused travelling to Edinburgh in congested traffic.In their statement supporting the countyrsquos need for the facility, the group said: ldquoLocal residentsare required to travel into Edinburgh, using the congested road network, in order to attend funeral services of their loved ones.ldquoSuchunpredictable journeys, on what is already a stressful day, are unacceptable.ldquoA new crematorium in this location will serve c., people as their closest crematorium and give c., the choice of a new, modern crematorium within a -minute funeral cortegravegedrive time.ldquoResidents of East Lothian and the surroundingcommunities would benefit from a modern facility that is closer totheir doorsteps.Planners have recommended the crematorium plans for the site, which is to the north of Old Craighall village, are approved when they go before councillors next week.In their report to elected members, planners said: ldquoThe applicant advises that office and cremation hours would be am to pm butinforms that cremations can sometimes go over : hours in busy periods, for instance a cold winter or a pandemic, when deaths are higher.ldquoAn ornamental garden, memorial garden and lsquoparklandrsquo feature would be formed around the crematorium building, with paths through them.ldquoWoodland tree and hedgerow planting is proposed to be undertaken around the perimeter of the site and within the site itself would betree and hedge planting and areas of amenity grasslands.Scotland has the lowest rate of cremations in the UK, with an estimated  percent of funerals cremations however, Westlerigh Group suggests this is down to a lack of facilities rather than choice.And the company says it is accepted in the industry that the average cortegravegetime for a funeral from the deceased personrsquos home to service should be no more than  minutes.Westerleigh Group says there are on average about , deaths in East Lothian every year.In their case for the new facility, they said: ldquoThere are vast areas within East Lothian Council that are not served within a benchmark -minute cortegravegedrive time of an existing crematoria.ldquoAll residents of East Lothian Council currently have to travel out of district, and the majorityhave to travel into Edinburgh for their nearest crematorium.ldquoThis often involves having to endure signicant delays to their journeys due to traffic build up on the City Bypass, the A and or local road networks into Edinburgh.ldquoThis causes the bereaved additional stress anda very poor qualitative experience.The committee will discuss the plans at a virtual meeting next week.

title: haddington-youngsters-recipe-book-helping-community-kitchen-project
story: Pupils at the townrsquos Compass School came up with the idea of collecting recipes from across the school community and publishing them as a recipe book.More than  copies were sold, with the profit of pound donated to Our Community Kitchen, which is based at the townrsquos bowling club.Earlier this month, the schoolrsquos pupil council was delighted to be able to hand over a cheque to Elaine Gale, from Our Community Kitchen.The charityrsquos aim is to bring people who are socially isolated from throughout the Haddington and Lammermuir area together to share home-cooked food in a relaxed and friendly environment, allowing for friendships to form.There are no barriers to age or ability, all are welcome.Ms Gale told the children more about the work of the charity on her visit to the school and thanked the school community for their support and generosity.Mark Becher, headteacher at the school, on Haddingtonrsquos West Road, was ldquoabsolutely delighted with the support the initiative received.He said: ldquoOur pupil council became aware of the work of the charity, particularly during the first lockdown when they ed to school, they wished to include the charity alongside those others which we choose to assist each year.ldquoWe received a fantastic response from the school community for recipes to be included in the book: from home-baking ideas to casseroles from soups to desserts.ldquoThe resulting publication proved to be very popular and,you can forgive the pun, sold like hot cakes!ldquoWe would like to publicly thank everyone who helped us and purchased a copy of the book.ldquoThrough their support, we have been able to raise a signicant amount for this important charity and support their invaluable work in the local community.

title: tributes-paid-local-radio-pioneer
story: One of the leading figures of the Scottish radio industry, he started his career in newspapers, including a spell with The Haddingtonshire Courier and the Daily Mail.He went on to become the first employee at Radio Clyde in , when he was appointed to set up and lead its news team. Just two years later, he moved to the east as head of news at Radio Forth to drive the new stationrsquos launch.Tom always considered himself a reporter, and once said: ldquoItrsquos what goes on in between the records that makes a station unique. Itrsquos all about whatrsquos going on in the area, cementing your roots in the community, with something for everyone and telling them yoursquore doing it.An illustration of that thinking came in winter , which saw much of Forthrsquos broadcast area come to a standstill after a sudden blizzard.Tom, who lived just outside Pencaitland, launched a week of emergency planned billed lsquoSnowlinersquo to help people in the community who had become stranded or were facing other dficulties caused by the weather, demonstrating the role that independent local radiocould play.He went on to become programme director, overseeing the creation of Forth  on FM and Forth  on AM, before taking over as managing director.He retired through ill health in .Luisa Cairns, then the newsroom secretary at Forth, said: ldquoIrsquom really shocked. I have too many memories of him to think of only one. Probably, like most othersrsquo recollections of him, I would say he was a very big character, kind, fair, meticulous and funny.John Collins wrote on Facebook: ldquoRIP Tom Steele. One of the ILR originals who launched Clyde and then Forth.ldquoHe was a man who was a bit mad, a bit scary and a bit perfect in equal measure. He convinced me it was OK to take a  per cent pay cut to join Forth.ldquoHe was a risk taker and a legend.Graham Bryce, chief operating officer of Bauer Media, which now owns Forth, said: ldquoTom was one of the driving forces behind Radio Forth as he was passionate about radio and doing the best for our listeners and the local area.ldquoLocal radio was very new in the UK at the time and Tom was at the forefront of the industry, which was recognised by the many awards and accolades he won over the years.

title: applications-open-funding-north-berwick-golf-clubs-community-fund
story: Since the fund was set up in , the club has received  applications and has helped  local organisations with more than pound, of support.The Firth of Forth Lobster Hatchery, East Lothian Yacht Club, Law Primary School, Coastal Communities Museum and North Berwick Community Council are among those to have benefited.A club spokesperson said: ldquoGiven the current climate, the club would like to continue to support local organisations. Having the ability to improve the lives of others within the local community is a privilege and one that comes with its own sense of obligation.ldquoFor many local organisations, small donations can make a startling dference to their ability to serve the community and continue the excellent work they do.ldquoWe believe thatwe can in some way benefit local organisations, it can help cement their future helping the community. One of our overarching aims it to build a lasting legacy in the local area.Those interested in applying should email feedback@northberwickgolf club for an application form.

title: cinema-tranents-fraser-centre-reopens-film-fans
story: The centre, on Winton Place, was refurbished in  and reopened in November of that year.But along with several other venues across the county, it was forced to close in March last year due to lockdown. It had only been able to host a few screenings before then.As most of Scotlandrsquos restrictions eased last month, which included cinemas being able to reopen and resume business, those at The Fraser Centre were planning theof its screenings.People visiting the centrersquos -capacity cinema will see a slight change as handrails have been added to the staircase that leads to seats positioned higher up, following requests from the publicAmong the movies planned in the coming weeks is the new James Bond film No Time To Die.All tickets are pound plus a booking fee per ticket, a special offer to celebrate the cinema opening once more. This price is available for films up to October . Tickets are non-refundable and can be booked at thefrasercentre films-live-eventsThere is limited capacity for all screenings, with social distancing in place. Facemasks must be worn by anyone aged over five unless they are exempt or eating drinking.It already held some screenings last week and there are more to come.On Thursday , The Last Bus is screened at pm.Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings is shown on Saturdayat pm, with Respect, a film about Aretha Franklin starring Jenner Hudson, following at pm.No Time To Die, Daniel Craigrsquos final outing as famous spy James Bond, is screened on October  at pm and pm, and again on October  at pm tickets pound .A thank you was shared to all of The Fraser Centrersquos sponsors and its programming partners INDY Cinema Group.David Orr, manager for The Fraser Centre Community Trust, said: ldquoWe are excited to introduce our cinema programme in The Fraser Centre.ldquoWith the venue on the site of the townrsquos old picture house, we have always planned to reintroduce cinema as part of our new award-winning building and we are delighted to share our opening programme for everyone to enjoy.Those interested in joining the cinema volunteer team are asked to visit thefrasercentre careers, volunteereastlothian.org.uk or call  . Weekend and midweek opportunities are available.

title: letter-week-not-impressed-number-campervans-north-berwick-seafront
story: This leaves no parking for anyone driving down there at the weekend andyou want to go onto the sand at the bottom of the steps by the water treatment plant, you have to cut through tables and chairs set up for their free holiday.Last weekend, there were  units parked up in a fairly small area, yet, being a campervan owner, I am fully aware that on a caravan site they have to keep you six metres apart to comply with fire regulations.One hopes East Lothian Council intervenes before something terrible happens.The motorhomes are often less than one metre apart, with fire pits and campfires set up each evening.On a visit to Ruby Bay in Fe recently, they had a large parking area for about  vehicles with seven designated for overnight parking on a first-come, first-served basis. This ensures that anyone staying overnight has sufficient space and seems like a sensible and proactive measure.The parking in Fe also had a public toilet: I can only hope that all of the campers in North Berwick are taking all of the contents of their toilet cassette and dirty dishwater home to be emptied there and that nothing is being dumped at the beach.We have a sign displayed here stating lsquoNo Overnight Parkingrsquo but this is a token gesture, as all motorhome owners know that this is not legally enforceable.I would like to see a change being made to ensure that the area is safe and for use by overnight tourists, day tourists and locals.Name and address suppliedAn East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWorking with our partners, we continue to actively consider action to support the responsible use of public land. This is important given the popularity of lsquostaycationsrsquo and the large number of visitors coming to East Lothian. In the meantime, we would encourage anyone who encounters vehicles parked in an unsafe way on the public road to make the authorities aware by contacting the police on .

title: families-remember-ancestors-lost-lives-sea-130-years-ago
story: Cousins and former pupils of Musselburgh Grammar School Jim Ritchie Johnston, , a Musselburgh resident, and Stuart Ritchie, , who now lives in Markinch, Fe, met at Fisherrow Harbour to remember their great grandfather James Ritchie.He drowned at the age of  after Star of the East was shipwrecked at the entrance to Lowestoft Harbour on November , , after the crew of eight set off from Fisherrow on September  that year.They were joined at a poignant family harbourside gathering by Mr Johnstonrsquos son Keith, a Musselburgh resident, and Mr Ritchiersquos sons Scottand Craig .Musselburgh resident Peter Millarrsquos great grandfatherrsquos brother John Williamson, a -year-old fisherman, also lost his le in the fishing tragedy.The boatrsquos skipper Walter Brown, aged , drowned as did his sons Walter, aged , and -year-old James, Alexander Brown, , and Robert Dickson, .The sole survivor of the tragedy was James Bonthron who reportedly clung to a piece of wreckage and was deaf from that time on.Simon Fairnie, of Musselburgh Museum, has researched the loss of The Star.He said: ldquoMany fishermen were lost at sea in the old days of sailing: one reason being that the herring fishing season occurred in early autumn and early winter when storms and gales were frequent.The  season had been patchy, with catches from September disappointing and the men of the Star of the East ndash a Fie which was a boat popular with the Fisherrow men ndash decided to try their luck further south.On November , explained Mr Fairnie, the fishing boat left Lowestoft for the fishing grounds and hauled about  barrels of herring before sailing for port at midnight.He said: ldquoBy .am a gale had reached its height and a wary approach was made to harbour.ldquoLowestoft in those days was regarded as dangerous to navigate. There were two lighthouses at the harbour entrance: one on a northern clf and the other to the south. These were intended to guide vessels through the portrsquos channel which had dangerous sand banks on either side.ldquoBut heavy rain prevented The Starrsquos crew from seeing the lights properly and there was a breakwater to be avoided before the harbour could be taken.ldquoOn entering the port, a huge wave bore down on the boat, threatening to throw it onto the breakwater.ldquoThe crew took what evasive action they could but, sadly, the boat was dashed against the masonry pier with such force that she quickly broke up with the tragic loss of all the crew but one.An active search was made but none of the bodies were reportedly found at that time.Almost five months later, the body of the skipper was found by fisherman William Cross, washed ashore at Dunwich, on March , .Newspapers reported at the time of memorial services being held in Musselburgh and visits made to grief-stricken families by the provost.Stuart Ritchie said it was believed that the skipperrsquos body was the only one found.He said: ldquoAfter a good deal of searching over a period of time, recently I found my great grandfatherrsquos death certicate. I feel very sad that, apparently, Jamesrsquos body was never found so a funeral may never have taken place.But he added: ldquoIt is good that the descendants are meeting up.ldquoIt would be even betterthe wider community in the Musselburgh Fisherrow area was made aware of this heritage and perhaps the local authority could do a bit to help here.He felt a lasting memorial to the crew of Star of the East at Fisherrow Harbour would be a fitting tribute to them.Mr Johnston added: ldquoAttending our harbour ceremony felt like stepping back into the past to remember and honour, not only James Ritchie and the other brave men of The Star who lost their lives, but also to allow us today to pay tribute to every family within the Fisherrow fishing community for the important contribution it has made to the economy and history of Musselburgh over many years.Walter Brown jnrrsquos great grandson Walter Moffat, , who lives in Toronto, Canada, visited the skipper Walter Brown snrrsquos grave at Dunwich in early  where a memorial stone had been placed by his widow Jane lsquoBonthronrsquo Brown.He said his ancestor was seen by commanding everyone to ldquosave themselves as he held the mast going down with the ship.ldquoCoincidentally, Walter Brown jnr forgot to take his bible on that trip ndash I have it at home, said his descendant who is the grandson of Walter Brown, the son of Walter Brown jr and Elizabeth Brown , who was just one when his father died in the shipwreck.The Scottish Fisheries Museum at Anstruther is planning to mark the th anniversary of the loss of The Star at its annual memorial service in the museumrsquos Memorial Room in October. The ceremony is organised in conjunction with the Fishermenrsquos Mission and is open to relatives of those lost.The names of the crew of The Star who died also look set to be listed in the museumrsquos memorial book which records the names of fishermen lost at sea prior to . Those from  onwards are recorded on brass plaques on the walls.Curator Linda Fitzpatrick said: ldquoThe entries are made at the request of family members and can reflect iniduals or entire crews of boats. They are not a complete record of all losses.ldquoThis ensures that we have the details correct and that we take account of family sensitivities.She added: The dangers of le at sea are all too well known and, often, the tragedy of a sinking was compounded by the fact that the men sailed with their relatives so that a father, husband, brother and son could be lost in a single incident.

title: tims-tales-shipwrecked-viking-andrews-legacy
story: I donrsquot remember the date I first saw this picture , but I remember the impact it had on me. It captures an imagined moment in which the legendary Viking Althamer sails along the coast of the Firth of Forth.It is the work of Andrew Hillhouse, an artist who sadly died in  at the young age of . I wish I had been wise enough to seek him out and talk with him about history and his art when Irsquod had the opportunity.His widow Vicky has told me of his modesty, that he wouldnrsquot call himself an artist because he was a working man with a job to pay the bills. He once wrote that he was ldquostill just a guy who likes to doodle in his spare time.Some doodles! His art is stunning: full of historical detail and atmosphere, and his work portrays many aspects of Scottish history, which was one of Andrewrsquos passions.His website has many more examples of his art, with short explanations to accompany them.He grew up in Prestonpans and knew the local legend of the townrsquos beginnings that it was founded by a Viking traveller named Althamer, who was shipwrecked with his crew on its rocky shore after a ferocious storm about a thousand years ago in the th century.As Andrew himself wrote: ldquoStories from this period are very dficult to very, but the legend persists to this dayhellip the image shows Althamerrsquos ship passing Bass Rock as the sun sets on the evening before their hard landing on Scotlandrsquos shores.But although this is a legend and not history, we do know that there was Viking activity around East Lothianrsquos shores in the th century. For example, it is recorded that the Norse king of Dublin, Olaf Guthfrithson, raided Tyninghame in AD and died soon afterwards.And perhaps he lies buried there. In , the farmer at Auldhame, Mr Dale, ploughed up bones. An archaeological dig took place and an Anglo Saxon monastery was revealed. A male skeleton was discovered buried there with items that identy him as being a high-ranking Norse warrior.It canrsquot be said for sure the skeleton was the remains of King Olaf himself. But itrsquos a fascinating possibility.The thing is, we have tiny historical glimpses of this time, with archaeology sometimes adding to our knowledge while also sometimes adding to the intrigue.To this, we can add the stories, told down the generations, at the firesides of the common folk. These stories often had their origin in an account of someonersquos experience, or a memory of an event, which then evolved to become part of folklore and legend.Since the story of Althamerrsquos arrival was set in a time of extensive Norse and Danish settlement, the idea of Prestonpans being founded by a shipwrecked Viking is not entirely fancul. There was, after all, a Viking settlement a few miles down the coast at Luffness, by Aberlady Bay.So Andrewrsquos image of Althamer and his crew sailing to their fate along the East Lothian coast is now part of the telling of this legend.The story lit my imagination and interest in history when I was a youngster growing up in Prestonpans. It still does.Irsquove often stood on its shore in a storm to watch the waves crash against the rocks in a rage, and see in my mindrsquos eye the Viking longboat being smashed.There is so much in this picture for you to discover, and it speaks more words than I can write.So I will leave it with you.It is produced here with thanks from Vicky Hillhouse, who gave her permission to use it on this page.But she has also kindly given permission for its use by local schoolchildren, who are now the younger custodians of the legend.

title: sight-loss-support-a-blessing-prestonpans-resident-agnes-78
story: Agnes Stevenson, , of Grant Road, received her age-related macular degeneration diagnosis in  when she was a full-time carer for husband Tom, who had dementia and passed away last year.Struggling with the impact of her sight loss, Agnes reached out to the charity Sight Scotland through its newly launched telephone support line ndash she has since praised the community service for helping her feel less alone.The Sight Scotland Support Line, launched across Edinburgh and the Lothians in January as part of the newly formed Family Wellbeing Service which launched last Wednesday, offers people with sight loss and their families someone to turn to for information, advice and support.The retired bookkeeper said: ldquoI didnrsquot know anything about macular degeneration.ldquoWhen I was told I had it, I was devastated.ldquoAt that time, I got no information at all.ldquoIt was a huge shock. If I had had support at an earlier point following my diagnosis, I donrsquot think I would have gone into such a depression.ldquoWhen you hear that your sight is going, you think: lsquoWhat am I going to do  How am I going to manage rsquoldquoYou canrsquot sleep for thinking about how yoursquore going to cope.ldquoI had given up completely. It made me quite depressed, thinking that nothing  could help with my sight.ldquoWhen I contacted Sight Scotland, Irsquod just thought: lsquoI have to do something. I cannot accept this.rsquoldquoThis is the first time I feel I have some support now. There was somebody there who would listen to me. Itrsquos been a blessing.Sight Scotlandrsquos Family Wellbeing Service team has provided emotional support to Agnes as she adapts to le with sight loss, including aiding her in regaining her much-loved sewing hobby.In addition to the telephone service, Sight Scotlandrsquos Family Wellbeing Service also provides the option of face-to-face home visits for people based in East Lothian.The Tranent-born resident said: ldquoOne of the Sight Scotland community workers, Debbie McGregor, has introduced me to dferent options and given me so much confidence. Shersquos been helping me with magniers and explaining how that can help. I see a future for myself and that is thanks to Sight Scotland.ldquoThere must be hundreds of people like me. The Sight Scotland Support Line can be a huge help for people impacted by sight loss.ldquoThere is somebody there for you. You donrsquot need to be alone.Sight Scotlandrsquos latest findings show out of  visually impaired people, more than  per cent said they had not had enough information about where to access support after this diagnosis.More than  per cent said it was important to provide more support to family members and carers.Mark OrsquoDonnell, chief executive of Sight Scotland and Sight Scotland Veterans, said: ldquoWe are proud to officially launch the Sight Scotland Support Line nationally. This new telephone service is there for anyone impacted by visual impairment so that no one in Scotland has to struggle with sight loss alone.People impacted by sight loss can call the Sight Scotland Support Line on   , Monday to Friday, am-pm, or visit SightScotland.org.uk for more information.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-1996-1971-1921
story: lsquoFEAR of cuts in hospital servicesrsquo was front page news in the East Lothian Courier on September , .Fears that local hospital services could be under threat to release cash for new hospital building in Edinburgh have led to a top-level meeting with Health Minister Lord James Douglas-Hamilton.Labour MP John Home Robertson, local councillors and health officials say they are seriously concerned by reports that, in the run-up to using private finance, Lothian Health Board will run down services such as day surgery at Roodlands Hospital, Haddington, where the casualty unit has already been withdrawn.And the MP promised ldquofierce resistancecuts to vital services were proposed.He was joined by East Lothian Councilrsquos social work chairman David Costello and Roodlands consultant Dr George Rhind for last weekrsquos meeting with Lord James at the Scottish Office.Mr Home Robertson demanded assurances about plans for the new Royal Infirmary at Little France as well as existing hospital services in East Lothian.lsquoBILLY the beer drinking budgie diesrsquo, The Haddingtonshire Courier of October ,  sadly reported!Regulars at the Plough Tavern, Haddington, were disappointed to find an empty cage in the bar last week. Billy the budgie had died.Billy, the chirpy green budgie, who had been the centre of attention in the bar during the past five years, used to delight customers with his antics.Billy, who never tasted water for eight years, could often be seen having a sip of beer from customersrsquo glasses. But he never touched spirits.ldquoHe preferred beer, said his owner, Mr Bill Reid, the proprietor of the Tavern, who used to breed budgerigars.ldquoMy we, Rena, and I had Billy since he hatched from an egg ndash  years ago.North Berwick High Schoolrsquos war memorial was unveiled, said The Haddingtonshire Courier of September , .On Friday, the memorial which has been placed in the High School was unveiled by Miss Lucy Hope, in the presence of a large gathering of present and former pupils, and relatives and friends of those whose names appear on the roll of honour.Among those present with Miss Hope and the Rectorwere:- Rev. James Davidson and Mr R Miller, members of the Education Authority Mr R. D. Robertson, M.A. B.Sc., Executive Officer of the Authority Dr Waddell, Provost Farquharson, Mr A D Wallace and Mr Graham, of the School Management Committee.

title: tesco-fresh-bid-avoid-paying-400k-interest-contributions-schooling-musselburgh
story: The food chain is appealing to Scottish Ministers to step in after East Lothian Council billed it four months afterconstruction started on  new homes on land formerly owned by the firm.Tesco had argued that it no longer had to pay the pound, educationcontribution tied to the new housing as it was no longer the owner of the land.But it lost its argument and an appeal against the decision was ruled lsquounlawfulrsquo.After being told it had to pay the bill, Tesco then applied to change the terms of the repaymentso it did not have to pay until the last house was completed rather than at the start of the development as previously agreed.The request was refused by the local authority, which now wants the bill paid with interest backdated to last year.The supermarket chain has now lodged an appeal with Scottish Ministers, asking them to overturn the councilrsquos decision so it can pay the bill at the end of the development and avoid the interest.East Lothian Council has argued that Tesco is getting off lightly after the deal over the land at its former store site at Olivebank was signed  years ago.They said thata similar deal was struck today, the contribution request would be closer to pound,.And they warned that a delay to the payment being made could ldquosignicantly impact ongoing projects to provide a new secondary school in Wallyford and extend Musselburgh Grammar School.Under planning legislation, local authorities can ask housing developers to pay a proportion of money towards schooling to counteract the additional number of families moving into their homes.Appealing against paying the contribution, Tesco argued: ldquoThis transactiontook place over a decade ago and the land of the residential developmentsite is not owned by Tesco.Rejecting Tescorsquos application, planning officers warned that Tesco was liable for interest rates of four per cent above the Bank of Scotland rate on the outstanding payment and the longer they took to pay, the more the value of the contribution was eroded by cost increases.They added that it would set a precedent for future infrastructure contributions which could put them at risk.The appeal has been lodged with the Scottish GovernmentReporters.

title: auction-big-hare-trail-statues-raises-115-000-leuchie-house

title: letters-tories-tune-1920s-2020s
story: Mr Smith references ldquoThatcher as the big Scottish Tory problem, but the Thatcher-era Secretary of State for Scotland was George Younger. Younger fought to keep steel making in Scotland. He fought to make Prestwick the main cargo hub in the UK, an eminently sensible idea. That he lost to vested southern interestsisnrsquot the issue.Contrast him with the present and previous Secretaries of State, Alister Jack and David Mundell. Like Scottish Tory MPs in general, they simply do not fight on any issue for what used to be called the ldquoScottish Interest. That is the problem for Mr Ross not ldquoclass.Add to that the advancement of an oligarch like Malcolm Offord, a man who apparently believes in cutting state expenditure by one-third , and it seems the Scottish Tories are more in tune with the s than the s. I do not regard ldquonationalism as a real issue in Scotland, butit were, then Mr Ross should be aware that ldquoScottish nationalism would always be preferred over ldquoBritish nationalism.GR Weir, Ochiltree.UNTRUTHS FROM DOUGLAS ROSSIT constantly amazes me ndash but why should it  ndash that politicians can twist the truth any which way they want. In the row over Labour deputy leader Angela Raynerrsquos comments regarding ldquoTory scum, the leader of the Scottish Conservatives suggests at the Tory conference she was referring to the votersand describes them as ldquonormal Scots looking for a party that can stand up to the SNP. They are people like me, my family and my community.Douglas Ross says: ldquoThese voters arenrsquot as Angela Rayner would say lsquovilersquo. They arenrsquot lsquonasty. They arenrsquot lsquoscumrsquo.Ms Rayner was reported as saying: "We cannot get any worse than a bunch of scum, homophobic, racist, misogynistic, absolute pile of banana republic, vile, nasty, Etonian, posh... piece of scum. Some quote that! But the fact is she wasnrsquot talking about the voters, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson and members of his party.So why is Mr Ross allowed to make  accusations and see them reported without any debate Is he simply following his leader and learning the best way forward is to continue to tell untruths because voters donrsquot know any better  And would he tell himself thatrsquos what ldquonormal Scots would expect Andy Stenton, Glasgow.SWISS SYSTEM WOULD HAVE SUITED USON one hand it is encouraging that Peter Russellrsquos proposal for a new Act of Union would include the right of one nation to "withdraw" unilaterally . It is though telling that the requirements he would impose for that nation to do so are not the traditional requirements of the UK polity. The tradition in the UK, which has been used in every election with the exception of the Scottish Assembly referendum in , has been ldquoone vote is enough.Philosophically I can understand Mr Russellrsquos point, but does he not recognise thatthere is to be such a rupture in UK tradition that there is some onus on him to justy this  Political expedience wrapped up in philosophical principle is not a justication for abandoning tradition.I would say Brexit was a major change, but had it come to it, one vote would have been enough. Brexit, as Mr Russell says, might have been a debacle, and like him I consider it a terrible act, but it is the tradition of how the UK does politics.Perhaps mindful of this, the majority requirements he cites are from other than the UK: Switzerland and the United States. The former is particularly interesting, since what he meansis that for a proposition to pass, there must be a national majority but also a majority of Cantons . Applied to the UK, Brexit would never have happened as two "cantons" ndash Scotland and Northern Ireland ndash voted Remain, so denying the double majority that would have been required, had this been the UK tradition. Politically that would have been most interesting in the UK but would be accepted in Switzerland as part of their political tradition.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.BREXIT HAS NOT FUELLED INDY VOTEI WOULD like to thank Ruth Marrfor her response to my letter of October . However, in doing so I fear all she has done is confirm the two main problems the independence movement suffers from: preaching only to the choir and deflecting away from the failures of the SNP.Ms Marr is absolutely right when she notes it is up to the unionists to make the case for the Union. What she and many of her fellow independence supporters fail to understand, and the point I was making, is that a similar burden rests on them to show why independence is better than the status quo. They failed to do this in  and need to convince people like me who voted against independence that it is worth it.I should point out that by Ms Marrrsquos own logic this should be simple. If it is better then it should be easy to list the places where Holyrood is better. Instead, the list of failings from both governments is staggering. While I am old enough to remember a time when the SNP was not in power at Holyrood, people currently reaching voting age are not. And they are much more likely to know who is in charge of what in Scotland and who to blame.As for her reference to Brexit, it should be noted that while Scots may not like Brexit, that does not mean they want to vote for independence to escape it. Support for independence did not increase after the Brexit vote it has not increased much in the years since. In fact, the only time support got above % for anyof time was when the SNP stopped talking about independence to deal with the pandemic. Food for thought there.John Shanks, Glasgow.FIGHT FOR A BETTER UNIONRUTH Marr states the untruth which she frequently peddles, about "crucial decisions affecting Scotland which are made at Westminster by a government Scotland did not elect". As Ms Marr knows only too well, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland has only one main government, democratically elected, and it is up to us to vote as we see fit when a General Election takes place then she states that "we are currently suffering the consequences of being dragged out of the European Union by a Tory government". As Ms Marr knows, we were dragged out of Europe because the majority of our population voted to do just that ndash not just against a healthy "no" vote from Scotland, but also many other areas of the UK, including London and its surrounding areas. Lastly she states "independence is normal for almost every other country in the world". Scotland is a normal country, and part of the United Kingdom, and therefore independent.I do not knowMs Marr has read Ian R Hamiltons book, No Stone Unturned, retelling the theft of the Stone of Destiny, but that gentleman ndash a strong nationalist ndash makes a fascinating statement as part of his introduction to his book: "If we do not solve the problem of Scottish government, people less moderate than we are will sweep us aside and make of Scotland another Ireland. Our fight is not for separation, but for a better Union, and as such we conceive it to be the concern of every one in the United Kingdom, whether he be Welsh or Irish, Scottish or English."Walter Paul, Glasgow.MOVE IN WITH THE NEIGHBOURSBRIAN Taylor implies that anything north of Hadrianrsquos Wall is part of Scotland , and lots of other writers equate the Scottish English border with Hadrianrsquos Wall. It would be a good ideawe made this a fact by annexing the north of Northumberland to Scotland. The countryside is beautul, the towns lively, and the people are friendly. This would help to "level up" the size of Scotland compared to England, and probably reduce the demand for Scottish independence.Helen Ross, Bridge of Allan.FRIENDLY DISAGREEMENTI WELCOME Michael Sheridanrsquos responseto Neil Mackayrsquos call that we should ldquodo better in the constitutional debate.Some of my best friends are adherents to the SNP cause. They are of course mistaken. But theyrsquore still my best friends.R Russell Smith, Largs.Read more: Keep tribalised blindness out of the Scottish independence debate

title: letters-wind-turbines-acceptable-price-pay-cleaner-power-supplies
story: As an engineer I personally find them pleasing works of design in appearance and fully acceptable in todays world. I have also visited Scotlands hills and coasts over many years, from Sutherland to the borders and all in between. Pylons and towers have not distracted my appreciation or love of our beautul land.Now aged  I recall my childhood in Bridgeton, Glasgow, walking to Hosier Street Primary in the late s in yellow smog-filled streets with my handkerchief tied round my nose and mouth. On removal the white hanky had two dark brown holes for nostrils. And all done four times per day, sometimes for days on end.The effect on Glasgow citizens health was immense in terms of lung disease. The cause was from coal-burning in every tenement and factory chimney.In time smoke controls were implemented but years of work then followed as the city erected scaffolding and buildings were shot-blasted to rediscover the beautul architecture hidden beneath the soot encrusted walls.Part of the Glasgow skyline was also peppered with huge structures called gasometers, like grotesque alien ships, for storing the city gas supplies. Great rusting hulks which rise and fall depending on the volume of gas inside. Not pretty to look at but necessary for the citizens needs at the time.Coal has gone. Nuclear has risks as in Fukashima and Three Rivers events. Oil is to be transitioned away from. So wind and solar has to be in the mix with possibly new hydrogen power options. We just cant have our pristine countryside and reliable power supplies without some penalties. Sorry, but it cant be done.Bob Wolfenden, Biggar.AVOID KNEE-JERK EVERARD RESPONSEI READ with interest the letter from Denis Bruce .He makes a number of well thought-out and well-intentioned suggestions, several of which are unfortunately unworkable.All the talk of ldquo the arrestee and about at least two officers and no handcuffs is commendable but would change nothing and could in fact make matters worse.Back in the day I made more than one off-duty arrest whilst alone. For example, one was in the middle of the night and it was an inidual who had broken into several cars and stolen a lot of property. Another was in the middle of the afternoon. I had become suspicious and followed an inidual into a very secluded wooded area. He was with a very young and very distressed child and I intervened seconds before before he raped her. He was a big man with inordinate strength. This was horric andMr Bruce had his way then presumably I would have had to just stand by Regarding handcuffs only for violent prisoners, then this takes no account of those who subsequently become violent or who secrete drugs or weapons on their person. They need to be secured before they can dispose of the drugs or use the weapon against the arresting officer.The events surrounding Sarah Everard are beyond evil. I truly cannot think of a more horric set of circumstances. I am confident that every serving and retired police officer , will be embarrassed, ashamed and mortied.I think it is incumbent on the entire police service , to carry out a root and branch reform of its recruitment processes and what should be far more stringent processes applicable to those who become authorised firearms officers . We currently have interviews, written exams, assessment processes for normal recruits and psychometric testing for AFOs but clearly this monster slipped through the net. The police service could take advice from other police agencies throughout the world and they could look at how operatives to our internal secret services within the UK are recruited. The police service clearly do not have a monopoly on all the answers.Something is wrong and needs fixed. It needs to be done calmly, and methodically. It cannot be done as a knee-jerk reaction.Stewart Falconer, Alyth.SCHOOL LIFE WAS JUST PANTSHOW things have changed from my time at a single-sex girls school from  to . I was reminded of what it was like when I saw the photo of the young ladies of St Columbas High School sanitising their handsI am afraid it wasnt the parents problem that interested me but whether the young ladies have to wear school knickers as "Victorian" as the ones in my day. I doubt it, as those pupils would probably not agree to wear the near-bloomers with strong elastic which were de rigueur. We had bottle-green oneswith a small pocket in which to keep ones handkerchief.The unorms we wore were tunics which came to the knee until, joy of joys, in the sixth form we were allowed to progress to skirts which came to near the ankles. It was the time of the "new look" so we felt very fashionable. I still wear skirts at ankle- and never trousers though I have given up on voluminous knickers with pockets.Thelma Edwards, Kelso.BOND WONT SAVE CINEMAWITH reference to the article by Karen Peattie film will be good for our economy", The Herald, October  it will take more than one Bond movie to revive cinema attendance.As a regular cinema attender prior to Covid my attendance has declined signicantly since restrictions eased. Not because of health concerns but because of the lack of quality films being released.The emergence of streaming channels during the pandemic has changed viewing habits, which could spell the longer-term demise of cinema attendance.Bill Eadie, Gfnock.

title: stormers-clash-golden-opportunity-mike-blairs-edinburgh-bounce-back-defeat
story: The South African side are zero from two in the competition so far and missing their Springbok stars. However, head coach Mike Blair believes that all four of the South African sides which have joined the league this year are getting stronger as they become accustomed to playing in European conditions, so has warned his team that they canrsquot afford to start slowly.ldquoTheyrsquore used to the type of game over here now with two games under their belts, Blair reasoned. ldquoStormers had an excellent first  minutes or so against Munster and not many teams go there and are  points up near half-time.ldquoMunster got back into it through their driving game, but Stormers when they hit their straps are a dficult team to stop.Blair added that while Edinburgh wonrsquot underestimate the challenge they face this coming weekend, the team will approach the match with confidence having quickly compartmentalised their loss to Benetton.ldquoWe had a team meeting and were frustrated, he explained. ldquoWe talked about shooting ourselves in the foot. But there was a load of positive stuff too, so it was a positive meeting about the good things that wersquove been doing.ldquoBut we did also reflect on the fact that we canrsquot give the opposition easy ins to the game through our basic errors, whether thatrsquos discipline or skill-based stuff.ldquoAfter  minutes we kicked the ball out on the full, and on  minutes  second wersquove got a line-out on their  to win the game, so you look back and of course yoursquore frustrated with how it turned out. But, as I said to the guys, itrsquos not asthese are dficult things to fix. We can turn these things around pretty quickly.ldquoThey were six wins from seven, playing at home, sowe had won that game that would have gone down as a really good away victory, he added. ldquoWe canrsquot then turn around and say it was a shocking loss.One of the big success stories for Edinburgh so far this season has been the form of Ben Vellacott, the -year-old scrum-half who joined the club from Wasps during the summer and has added an energy to the capital outfitrsquos play which was conspicuously absent last season under Richard Cockerill.Vellacottrsquos recruitment may have happened before Blair took up the capital reins, but the coach has been a long-time admirer.ldquoHersquos done well, hasnrsquot he  said Blair. ldquoHersquos someone we watched nationally for a few seasons. He had a bad knee injury [in September ] and didnrsquot get a huge amount of rugby after that. I was in touch with him a couple of years ago and gave him a bit of feedback on a few dferent things.ldquoHersquos an exceptional player. Give him front foot ball and hersquos going to tear the opposition apart. And the pleasing thing with Ben is hersquos not been a one-trick pony. Hersquos been able to play at tempo. but hersquos shown a really good organisation as well.As the nationrsquos most capped scrum-half and a former member of Gregor Townsendrsquos Scotland coaching team, Blair is ideally placed to assess whether the new man has got what it takes to push his way into the international frame this autumn.ldquoI think Scotland have strong scrum-halves, and George [Horne] and Ali [Price] probably have a fair bit in the bank, but the way that Ben is going,he can continue to show this consistency, hersquoll start pushing those two along with Jamie Dobie and Scott Steele, Blair said.Vellacottrsquos fine form has not been good news for the two other scrum-halves in the Edinburgh squad, with -year-old Henry Pyrgos managing eight minutes off the bench in round one against the Scarlets and -year-old Charlie Shiel being an unused sub against Benetton.This lack of game time is a particular concern with respect to Shiel, who has been on the books since the summer of  and has  appearances to his name, but only  starts. He is a player who has been on the verge of a breakthrough for three years, without ever getting a real run in the team.ldquoIt is dficult, said Blair. ldquoI am trying to give guys opportunities, but we donrsquot have Super we can fall back on because Covid means we need a week between playing Super and then coming back with us.ldquoI am as frustrated as these guys are because I am giving them feedback and telling them what they need to show, and the guys are saying: lsquoI know, but Irsquom not playing!rsquoldquoI know that answer is coming so I need to be able to facilitate ways for the guys to show me what they can do in training.

title: facebook-whatsapp-instagram-outages-explained
story: The s had confirmed on Twitter they were aware of issues and working to resolve them after thousands of people reported outages shortly before pm on Monday.Users were eventually able to access Facebook and Instagram from late on Monday evening, while WhatsApp said its services were ldquoback and running at % as of .am on Tuesday.Facebook said a ldquofaulty configuration change on its routers was believed to be at the centre of the outage.It said in a statement: ldquoOur engineering teams have learned that configuration changes on the backbone routers that coordinate network traffic between our data centres caused issues that interrupted this communication.ldquoThis disruption to network traffic had a cascading effect on the way our data centres communicate, bringing our services to a halt.ldquoWe want to make clear at this time we believe the root cause of this outage was a faulty configuration change. We also have no evidence that user data was compromised as a result of this downtime.The  added it was working to understand more about the outage in order to ldquomake our infrastructure more resilient.In a statement posted to Twitter at .pm on Monday, Facebook apologised for the outage and thanked its millions of users around the world ldquofor bearing with us.It said: ldquoTo the huge community of people and businesses around the world who depend on us: wersquore sorry.ldquoWersquove been working hard to restore access to our apps and services and are happy to report they are coming back online now. Thank you for bearing with us.Data on the web service monitoring  DownDetector showed that almost , people had reported the outages on Facebook by just after pm.Most complaints cited issues with the website , while others were linked to issues with the server connection and the app.Moe than , had complained about WhatsApp, with % reporting issues with the app itself, while % cited the server connection and % relating to sending messages.More than , Instagram users also had similar complaints, with % relating to the app, % over the server connection and % citing the website.A graph on the DownDetector website showed a clear spike from after pm.Facebookrsquos share price plummeted .% amid the outage, which also came the day after a whistleblower claimed in a US interview that the company prioritises its own interests over the public good.The s were affected by outages in  ndash in an incident which saw #FacebookDown, #instagramdown and #whatsappdown trending worldwide on Twitter.A few months prior, users of Facebook and Instagram reported being unable to open pages or sections on the apps.The issue also affected other s such as Twitter amid an increase in traffic on its website and app.Twitter Support tweeted: ldquoSometimes more people than usual use Twitter. We prepare for these moments, but today things didnrsquot go exactly as planned.ldquoSome of you may have had an issue seeing replies and DMs as a result. This has been fixed. Sorry about that!It had earlier joked: ldquoHello literally everyone.

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
